This table represents a detailed table of contents from what appears to be an annual report or similar financial document. It is organized into four parts (I-IV) with multiple items in each section. The document spans 58 pages and covers various aspects of business operations, financial statements, risk factors, corporate governance, and other regulatory disclosures. Key sections include business operations, financial condition analysis, executive compensation, and corporate governance matters. Most items have specific page references, with Part III items notably all beginning on page 57.

data.value: Insperity, Inc. provides an array of human resources and business solutions designed to improve business performance.

PEO HR Outsourcing Solutions, Workforce Optimization, Workforce Synchronization, traditional payroll, human capital management, Recruiting Services, Employment Screening, Retirement Services, and Insurance Services.
Insperity and its clients take responsibility for portions of the employer-employee relationship.
Compensate WSEEs through wages, pay employer payroll taxes, withhold employee payroll taxes, provide employee benefits, and provide workersâ€™ compensation insurance.
Revenue is recognized ratably over the payroll period as services are rendered.

data.value: Group health insurance coverage provided under a single-employer plan for WSEEs in PEO HR Outsourcing Solutions and corporate employees.
Includes UnitedHealthcare, Kaiser Permanente, Blue Shield of California, and others.
Approximately 87% of health insurance costs are through UnitedHealthcare.
Partially self-funded insurance accounting model adopted.
Claims exceeding $1 million are not the financial responsibility of the company.
Costs recorded as benefits expense in Consolidated Statements of Operations.
Based on claims processed, development patterns, and participant numbers.

elements.title: MANAGEMENTâ€™S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS

data.value: Other income (expense) was a net expense of $4.8 million, $5.0 million, and $5.4 million in 2022, 2021 and 2020, respectively. In 2022, the increase in other income was due to an increase in interest income on our marketable securities investments and workersâ€™ compensation deposits, which was offset by an increase in interest expense related to higher average interest rates on borrowings under our credit facility.

Our effective income tax rate was 26.9% in 2022, 26.3% in 2021 and 27.0% in 2020. Our provision for income taxes differed from the U.S. statutory rate of 21% primarily due to state income taxes and non-deductible expenses, offset by excess tax benefits associated with the vesting of equity compensation of $0.2 million, $2.6 million and $2.1 million, in 2022, 2021 and 2020, respectively.

Non-GAAP financial measures are not prepared in accordance with GAAP and may be different from non-GAAP financial measures used by other companies. Non-GAAP financial measures should not be considered as a substitute for, or superior to, measures of financial performance prepared in accordance with GAAP.

elements.title: Managementâ€™s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations

data.value: Our gross profit per WSEE and our operating results are significantly impacted by our ability to accurately estimate, control and manage our direct costs relative to the revenues derived from the markup component of our gross billings.
Our pricing objectives attempt to achieve a level of revenue per WSEE that matches or exceeds changes in primary direct costs and operating expenses.
Our revenues per WSEE per month increased $25 due to higher average pricing.
Our direct costs per WSEE per month increased $12 primarily due to changes in direct costs.
The net increase in direct costs between 2022 and 2021 attributable to changes in cost estimates for benefits and workersâ€™ compensation totaled $6.7 million.
The cost of group health insurance and related employee benefits decreased $9 per WSEE per month but increased 1.2% on a per covered employee basis.

elements.title: Risk Factors Related to Healthcare Claims and Unemployment Trends

data.value: Changes in treatment delivery options may continue to significantly alter health care claim trends.

elements.title: Labor Shortages and Inflation Risk Factors

data.value: Labor shortages and increasing competition for highly skilled workers could have a material adverse effect on the business, financial condition or results of operations.

High employment levels, strong macroeconomic conditions, and government regulations may limit available labor and increase costs.
Inflationary pressure could adversely impact profitability, increasing operating costs that may not be fully offset by price raises.

elements.title: Estimation of the Cost of Incurred Workersâ€™ Compensation Claims

data.value: The Company provides workersâ€™ compensation insurance, including ongoing health care and indemnity coverage, to its employees whereby claims are paid over numerous years following the date of injury.
The Company has financial responsibility for a significant portion of the workersâ€™ compensation claims.
The accrual related to incurred costs is recorded in accrued workersâ€™ compensation costs in the consolidated balance sheets.
The estimated accrued claims are based on the loss development rate and discount rates.
